recipe.title: Pork Chops & Spring Vegetable Hash   with Homemade Ranch Dressing
recipe.description: Bright, crisp snow peas are among the season’s finest produce. In this recipe, they add plenty of springtime freshness to our vegetable hash. We’re briefly cooking our snow peas before combining them with browned potatoes, radishes and onion as a side for pan-seared pork chops. And we’re completing the dish with a lighter take on classic ranch dressing—made simply with tart yogurt, lemon juice and a signature blend of herby, zesty seasonings.

stories.title: Greek Yogurt
stories.description: Greek yogurt is yogurt that has been strained to remove the liquid whey, leaving a thicker, creamier texture as well as a higher protein content than regular yogurt. It’s been enjoyed in Eastern Europe, North Africa and Asia for centuries. Thanks to its thickness, it’s excellent in cooking, especially as the base of cooling yogurt sauces, as a marinade or as a substitute for buttermilk or heavy cream.

stories.title: Snow Peas
stories.description: Crunchy snow peas, also known as Chinese pea pods, are known for their flat shaped pods and small peas. Like snap peas, the entirety of the legume is edible. Snow peas can be enjoyed raw or cooked, and they’re a particular favorite in stir-fries. They have a mild, refreshing flavor and pleasantly crisp texture.

stories.title: Radish
stories.description: The root of a plant in the mustard family, (it’s name comes from the Latin “radix”, meaning root), the radish has been eaten since prehistoric times. It comes in a variety of shapes and colors, with flavors ranging from mild to peppery, and has a crispy, crunchy texture. It was brought to the United States by Spanish and Portuguese colonists—today, Florida is a major grower of radishes. It’s a favorite in salads, where it’s typically enjoyed raw.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Lemon
stories.description:
Lemon, though we may take it for granted, is one of the most important ingredients in any kitchen. Its light, pure acidity provides a vivid contrast that brightens the other flavors of countless dishes.

The most common lemons, which we use in virtually all of our dishes, are Eureka lemons. They've been grown in the United States (specifically California) since the 1850s, from Sicilian seeds. This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.title: Yukon Gold Potatoes
stories.description: These thin-skinned, golden-fleshed potatoes are a relative newcomer to the agricultural market (they were developed by Canadian researchers in the 1960s), but their popularity is no surprise. They are often referred to as an “all-purpose” potato, as they are excellent in any number of preparations, including boiling, baking, roasting and frying. When cooked, they become especially creamy in texture, with a delicious, buttery flavor.

stories.title: Yellow Onion
stories.description: This unassuming Allium likely originated in Central Asia or the Middle East and has been cultivated for at least 5,000 years. The Egyptians thought the onion symbolized eternal life—frequently, Egyptian priests are depicted holding onions in art from the time. For many ancient civilizations, like those of China, India, Greece and Rome, onions were considered to have medicinal properties. To help improve their performance before Olympic competition, Ancient Greek athletes consumed onions by the pound. Today, we use yellow onions—considered the universal, all-purpose onion—for their robust layers and spicy, sharp and sweet flavor profile.

ingredients.description: Ranch Spice Blend (Onion Powder, Garlic Powder, Whole Dried Chives, Whole Dried Parsley & Whole Dried Celery Seeds)
ingredients.customer_facing_name: 1 Tablespoon Ranch Spice Blend (Onion Powder, Garlic Powder, Whole Dried Chives, Whole Dried Parsley & Whole Dried Celery Seeds)
ingredients.customer_facing_ingredient_name: Tablespoon Ranch Spice Blend (Onion Powder, Garlic Powder, Whole Dried Chives, Whole Dried Parsley & Whole Dried Celery Seeds)

stories.title: Ranch Spice Blend
stories.description:
The familiar, zesty flavors of ranch dressing are deliciously recreated in this gourmet spice blend, which combines onion and garlic powders, fragrant whole dried chives, whole dried parsley and the pleasant, slightly bitter flavor of whole dried celery seeds.

2 Parts Onion Powder

2 Parts Garlic Powder

2 Parts Whole Dried Chives

1 Part Whole Dried Parsley

1 Part Whole Dried Celery Seed

recipe_steps.step_text: In a large pan, heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the potatoes in a single, even layer; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 14 to 16 minutes, or until softened and browned on all sides. Transfer a medium bowl and set aside in a warm place. Wipe out the pan.

Pat the pork chops dry with paper towels; season with salt and pepper on both sides. In the pan used to cook the potatoes, heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the seasoned pork chops and cook 3 to 4 minutes per side, or until browned and cooked through. Transfer to a plate, leaving any browned bits (or fond) in the pan. Loosely cover the cooked pork chops with aluminum foil and set aside to rest for at least 5 minutes.

While the potatoes cook, add the snow peas to the pot of boiling water. Cook 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until bright green. Drain thoroughly and rinse under cold water for 20 to 30 seconds to stop the cooking process. Transfer to the bowl of cooked potatoes.

Wash and dry the fresh produce. Heat a small pot of salted water to boiling on high. Medium dice the potatoes. Halve the snow peas crosswise on an angle. Peel and medium dice the onion. Cut the radishes into bite-sized pieces. Peel and mince the garlic. Quarter and deseed the lemon.

stories.title: How To: Quarter and Deseed a Lemon
stories.description: Lemons are indispensable to cooking. Their tart juice brightens other flavors and can tie a dish together. We’ve come up with an easy way to get the juice out of the lemon (without having to deal with the pesky seeds). Watch this short video to see how it’s done.

stories.title: How To: Dice a Potato
stories.description: Cut large for roasting, or small for soups and stews, there’s a special trick to quickly dicing a potato. Check out the video to see how our chefs do it.

stories.title: How To: Properly Salt Cooking Water
stories.description: Seasoning cooking water (whether you're cooking pasta, vegetables or anything else) is imperative to building flavor. Check out this video to see how we do it!

stories.title: How To: Mince Garlic
stories.description: What would cooking be without garlic? Minced garlic helps create an amazing flavor base for virtually any meal. In this short video, chef Matt Wadiak will show you how to mince garlic in no time.

stories.title: How To: Hold a Chef's Knife
stories.description: At the core of many knife skills in holding the knife properly. This simple grip gives you all the power and freedom you’ll need to prep whatever’s on your cutting board. So get a grip and watch this short video to see how it’s done!

recipe_steps.step_text: While the hash cooks, in a small bowl, combine the yogurt, spice blend and the juice of the remaining lemon wedges; season with salt and pepper to taste. Divide the finished hash and rested pork chops between 4 dishes. Serve with the ranch dressing on the side. Enjoy!
recipe_steps.step_title: Make the ranch dressing & serve your dish:

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the pork chops rest, add the onion, radishes and 2 tablespoons of water to the pan of reserved fond; season with salt and pepper. Cook on medium-high, stirring frequently and scraping up any fond from the bottom of the pan, 2 to 4 minutes, or until slightly softened and browned. Add the garlic, cooked potatoes, cooked snow peas and 1 teaspoon of olive oil; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 1 to 2 minutes, or until thoroughly combined. Turn off the heat. Add the juice of 2 lemon wedges; season with salt and pepper to taste.

stories.title: Ranch Spice Blend
stories.description:
The familiar, zesty flavors of ranch dressing are deliciously recreated in this gourmet spice blend, which combines onion and garlic powders, fragrant whole dried chives, whole dried parsley and the pleasant, slightly bitter flavor of whole dried celery seeds.

2 Parts Onion Powder

2 Parts Garlic Powder

2 Parts Whole Dried Chives

1 Part Whole Dried Parsley

1 Part Whole Dried Celery Seed

This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.description: What would cooking be without garlic? Minced garlic helps create an amazing flavor base for virtually any meal. In this short video, chef Matt Wadiak will show you how to mince garlic in no time.

stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

stories.title: How To: Hold a Chef's Knife
stories.description: At the core of many knife skills in holding the knife properly. This simple grip gives you all the power and freedom you’ll need to prep whatever’s on your cutting board. So get a grip and watch this short video to see how it’s done!

recipe.title: Chicken Khao Soi with Crispy Wonton Noodles
recipe.description: Tonight we’re cooking up khao soi, a Northern Thai favorite with Burmese influences. This soup achieves the perfect balance of sweet and savory with its coconut curry-based broth. We’re filling ours with chicken, kale, fresh wonton noodles and more. And to top it off, we’re pan-frying some of the noodles for a special garnish. If there’s not enough space in your pot to spread out all the noodles at once, be sure to fry them in batches instead—they need direct contact with the hot oil to develop the perfect crunch!

stories.title: Fresh Wonton Noodles
stories.description: Thin and springy, fresh wonton noodles are the star of any dish they’re served in. The chewy, fast-cooking, egg-based noodles are especially popular in wonton noodle soup, although they can also be enjoyed as a side dish, or fried for a crispy garnish.

stories.title: Coconut Milk
stories.description: Made from the pressed pulp of the coconut fruit, coconut milk is a creamy, mildly sweet liquid that is an essential ingredient in Southeast Asian, Caribbean and South American cooking. It’s often used in curries, soups or stews, where it makes an effective cooling agent to balance the spicier components of the dish. Chefs, one note: the rich milk can naturally separate over time, causing the coconut cream to settle in the can—giving the can a quick shake before you open it will ensure a smooth, combined product!

stories.title: Lime
stories.description: One of the most acidic citrus fruits, limes likely originated in Southeast Asia. There are several types of limes, but the variety most commonly enjoyed in the U.S. is the Persian lime, known for its plump, seedless flesh and dark green skin. If allowed to ripen to maturity, limes actually turn yellow, but they're harvested when green for superior flavor (and to avoid confusion with lemons!).

stories.title: Scallions
stories.description: Scallions, an onion relative, belong to a class of plants with undeveloped root bulbs and long, hollow leaves. They're milder than most other onion plants and delicious both cooked and raw. (In our recipes, you'll typically cook the white bottoms and use the green tops as garnish, reflecting the difference in their potency.) Scallions are a wonderful addition to everything from scrambled eggs to soups to stir-fries.

stories.title: Curly Kale
stories.description: With its crinkly, frilly leaves, curly kale is almost as beautiful to look at as it is delicious to eat. It’s grown mainly for autumn and winter harvests, as the cool weather actually enhances the kale's inherent sweetness. Although many of our recipes call for the fibrous center rib of the kale to be removed before the leafy green is used, the rib is actually fully edible. When chopped up finely, it makes an excellent addition to soups and stocks!

stories.title: Ginger
stories.description: This delicious, knobby root is native to southern China, and from there it spread to the Spice Islands (in present-day Indonesia), West Africa and the Caribbean. Ginger began appearing in Europe in the 1st Century. Botanically, it's most closely related to turmeric, cardamom and galangal, but it has a distinct flavor. Ginger has very many uses, both candied and pickled. It also has natural preservative qualities. And while we love it in all forms, we like it best minced and added to dishes where its lightly spicy, fresh flavor can truly shine.

stories.title: Yellow Curry Paste
stories.description: We love this Thai curry paste for its incredible depth of flavor, which is used to liven up curries, stews, meat or fish. Generally made from a blend of chiles, spices and traditional Thai aromatics, it has a milder heat level than green or red curry paste. It gets its gorgeous yellow color from turmeric (a powerful spice related to ginger that has a delicious, pungent flavor).

stories.title: Coconut Palm Sugar
stories.description: This ingredient is made from the sap of the coconut palm. It's an unrefined sugar, similar to jaggery, with a mellow sweetness. Because it's not processed, it retains many of its nutrients (yes, sugar can be good for you!).

stories.title: Soy Sauce
stories.description: Soy sauce is a millennia-old flavoring sauce made from soy beans. The beans are cooked, chopped, combined with flour and made into a paste. Then they're dried and left, mixed with water and salt and allowed to ferment. The process can take several months. But after it's pressed out, the sauce is so delicious that it's formed the basis of countless Asian cuisines.

recipe_steps.step_text: Add the kale to the pot of chicken and aromatics; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until wilted. Add the palm sugar, soy sauce, coconut milk (shaking the can just before opening) and 1 cup of water. Reduce the heat to medium and simmer, stirring occasionally, 3 to 5 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through and the liquid is slightly reduced in volume. Turn off the heat. Stir in the juice of 4 lime wedges; season with salt and pepper to taste.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the soup simmers, add the remaining noodles to the pot of boiling water. Cook 2 to 4 minutes, or until tender. Drain thoroughly. Divide the cooked noodles and finished soup between 4 bowls. Top with the crispy noodles. Garnish with the green tops of the scallions and remaining lime wedges. Enjoy!
recipe_steps.step_title: Cook the noodles & serve your dish:

recipe_steps.step_text: In the pot used to make the crispy noodles, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the seasoned chicken and cook, stirring occasionally, 8 to 10 minutes, or until browned.

Wash and dry the fresh produce. Heat a medium pot of salted water to boiling on high. Cut off and discard the root ends of the scallions; thinly slice the scallions on an angle, separating the white bottoms and green tops. Peel and mince the ginger. â€‹Remove and discard the kale stems; roughly chop the leaves. Quarter the limes. Pat the chicken dry with paper towels and chop into bite-sized pieces; place in a bowl. Season the chopped chicken with salt and pepper; toss to coat.

stories.title: How To: Hold a Chef's Knife
stories.description: At the core of many knife skills in holding the knife properly. This simple grip gives you all the power and freedom you’ll need to prep whatever’s on your cutting board. So get a grip and watch this short video to see how it’s done!

stories.title: How To: Properly Salt Cooking Water
stories.description: Seasoning cooking water (whether you're cooking pasta, vegetables or anything else) is imperative to building flavor. Check out this video to see how we do it!

stories.title: How To: Peel & Mince Ginger
stories.description: Ginger is a common, aromatic ingredient popular in cuisines throughout the world. Because of its knobby shape, prepping ginger can seem tricky. But simply follow the instructions in this video and you'll be prepping like a pro.

stories.title: How To: Chop Scallions
stories.description: Scallions, or green onions, are one of our favorite aromatic vegetables. There are two parts of the vegetable: the white bottom and the green top. They're used a little differently in cooking—the white bottoms are similar in use to regular onions and are usually cooked; the green tops are often used raw as a garnish. In our recipes, we specify to separate them. Check out this video to see how we do it.

stories.title: How To: Separate Leafy Greens from the Stems
stories.description: Check out this simple trick for separating the stems and leaves of one of our favorite ingredients: kale. You won't even need a knife!

recipe_steps.step_text: Add the ginger and white bottoms of the scallions to the pot of chicken; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until softened and fragrant. Add as much of the curry paste as you’d like, depending on how spicy you’d like the dish to be. Cook, stirring frequently, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until the curry paste is toasted and fragrant.

In a large pot, heat a thin layer of oil on medium-high until hot. Using your hands, gently separate the noodles. Add ¼ of the noodles to the pot in a single, even layer. (If necessary, work in batches.) Cook, tossing occasionally to separate the noodles and coat them in oil, 2 to 4 minutes, or until lightly browned and crispy. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate and immediately season with salt. Set aside in a warm place. Carefully discard the oil and wipe out the pot.

stories.title: Fresh Wonton Noodles
stories.description: Thin and springy, fresh wonton noodles are the star of any dish they’re served in. The chewy, fast-cooking, egg-based noodles are especially popular in wonton noodle soup, although they can also be enjoyed as a side dish, or fried for a crispy garnish.

stories.title: Yellow Curry Paste
stories.description: We love this Thai curry paste for its incredible depth of flavor, which is used to liven up curries, stews, meat or fish. Generally made from a blend of chiles, spices and traditional Thai aromatics, it has a milder heat level than green or red curry paste. It gets its gorgeous yellow color from turmeric (a powerful spice related to ginger that has a delicious, pungent flavor).

It’s often used in curries, soups or stews, where it makes an effective cooling agent to balance the spicier components of the dish. recipe.title: Crispy Catfish & Paella-Style Rice with English Peas & Creamy Saffron Aioli
recipe.sub_title: with English Peas & Creamy Saffron Aioli
recipe.description: Paella is one of Spain’s most treasured culinary traditions. The wholesome rice dish, often prepared with seafood, is beloved for its vibrant flavor and color. In this recipe, we’re serving fried catfish with paella-inspired rice. In true Spanish fashion, after simmering it with spices, tomatoes and fresh peas, we’re pan-toasting the rice to create a satisfyingly crispy layer on the bottom. (And to preserve this layer of texture, we’re serving the rice straight out of the pan.) A condiment of creamy saffron aioli truly puts this dish over the top.

stories.title: Arborio Rice
stories.description: Because of its high concentration of a starch known as amylopectin, arborio rice has a unique texture when cooked: pleasantly creamy, but without losing its distinctive “bite”. This signature characteristic makes it a favorite rice for use in risotto. It’s named for the town of Arborio in the Piedmont region of Italy (where it was first grown). It has oval-shaped grains with a beautiful, pearly white exterior.

stories.title: English Peas
stories.description: Technically a kind of legume (like beans or lentils), peas are native to Western Asia. They’ve been cultivated since the Bronze Age. They spread to India and China by the 7th Century. (In Chinese, the word for pea translates to “foreign legume.”) During that time, peas (also called “field peas”) were quickly becoming a staple of European Medieval cuisine. These cuisines featured almost exclusively the pea itself (the seed of the plant). They’re still delicious and another sign that spring has sprung!

stories.title: Scallions
stories.description: Scallions, an onion relative, belong to a class of plants with undeveloped root bulbs and long, hollow leaves. They're milder than most other onion plants and delicious both cooked and raw. (In our recipes, you'll typically cook the white bottoms and use the green tops as garnish, reflecting the difference in their potency.) Scallions are a wonderful addition to everything from scrambled eggs to soups to stir-fries.

stories.title: Lemon
stories.description:
Lemon, though we may take it for granted, is one of the most important ingredients in any kitchen. Its light, pure acidity provides a vivid contrast that brightens the other flavors of countless dishes.

The most common lemons, which we use in virtually all of our dishes, are Eureka lemons. They've been grown in the United States (specifically California) since the 1850s, from Sicilian seeds. This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.title: All-Purpose Flour
stories.description: The term “all-purpose flour” is used to describe wheat flour with a low to moderate protein content. All-purpose flour has less protein than bread flour (which more easily forms gluten to make dense, chewy bread), but more protein than airy cake or pastry flour. It can be used in a wide variety of applications and is considered an essential pantry ingredient for bakers and chefs alike.

stories.title: Mayonnaise
stories.description: This thick, creamy sauce is the result of a unique process known as emulsion—or a blend of two liquids wherein one forms tiny droplets that are suspended in the other. In the case of traditional mayonnaise, oil droplets are evenly dispersed in a mixture of egg yolk, water and lemon juice or vinegar. By slowly whisking the oil into the base of egg yolk, water and acid, it breaks into small droplets, thickening the mixture and creating mayonnaise’s signature consistency. Although frequently used as a condiment, mayonnaise also makes an excellent ingredient in dressings, and it’s a favorite to lock in moisture when breading meat or poultry.

stories.title: Saffron Powder
stories.description: At once delicate and powerful in flavor, saffron has long been one of the world’s most prized spices. Made from the crocus of the saffron flower, the powder is gorgeously red, and when added to a dish, it will often turn it a deep, striking yellow. Because it takes thousands of saffron crocuses to produce just one ounce of saffron powder, it is celebrated for its rarity. It has a complex, powerful aroma and taste—just the smallest pinch can add its distinct, unforgettable notes to a dish.

ingredients.description: Paella Spice Blend (Smoked Paprika & Garlic Powder)
ingredients.customer_facing_name: 1 Tablespoon Paella Spice Blend (Smoked Paprika & Garlic Powder)
ingredients.customer_facing_ingredient_name: Tablespoon Paella Spice Blend (Smoked Paprika & Garlic Powder)

recipe_steps.step_text: Wash and dry the fresh produce. Cut off and discard the root ends of the scallions; thinly slice the scallions on an angle, separating the white bottoms and green tops. Shell the peas. Pick the parsley leaves off the stems; discard the stems. Quarter and deseed the lemon. Pat the catfish fillets dry with paper towels and cut in half crosswise; place in a bowl.

stories.title: How To: Hold a Chef's Knife
stories.description: At the core of many knife skills in holding the knife properly. This simple grip gives you all the power and freedom you’ll need to prep whatever’s on your cutting board. So get a grip and watch this short video to see how it’s done!

stories.title: How To: Quarter and Deseed a Lemon
stories.description: Lemons are indispensable to cooking. Their tart juice brightens other flavors and can tie a dish together. We’ve come up with an easy way to get the juice out of the lemon (without having to deal with the pesky seeds). Watch this short video to see how it’s done.

stories.title: How To: Chop Scallions
stories.description: Scallions, or green onions, are one of our favorite aromatic vegetables. There are two parts of the vegetable: the white bottom and the green top. They're used a little differently in cooking—the white bottoms are similar in use to regular onions and are usually cooked; the green tops are often used raw as a garnish. In our recipes, we specify to separate them. Check out this video to see how we do it.

recipe_steps.step_text: In a large pot, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the rice, spice blend and white bottoms of the scallions; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until fragrant. Add the tomatoes and 3½ cups of water; season with salt and pepper. Heat to boiling on high. Once boiling, reduce the heat to medium-low. Add the peas. Simmer, stirring frequently, 16 to 18 minutes, or until the rice is tender and most of the liquid has been absorbed. (If the mixture seems dry, add up to ¼ cup of water to achieve your desired consistency.)

Add the cooked rice to the pan used to cook the catfish. Using a spoon or spatula, press the rice into the pan; cook on medium-high, without stirring, 2 to 3 minutes, or until the rice begins to crisp and retract from the sides of the pan. Remove from heat.

While the rice continues to cook, season the catfish with salt and pepper; toss to coat. In a large pan (nonstick, if you have one), heat a thin layer of oil on medium-high until hot. Once the oil is hot enough that a drop of batter sizzles immediately when added to the pan, working in batches, thoroughly coat the seasoned catfish in the batter (letting any excess drip off). Carefully add the coated catfish to the pan. Cook 4 to 5 minutes per side, or until golden brown and crispy. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate; immediately season with salt. Set aside in a warm place. Carefully discard the oil and wipe out the pan.

Transfer the cooked catfish to a serving dish. Serve the finished rice out of the pan (or transfer to a serving dish, if you’d like). Garnish with the green tops of the scallions and parsley. Serve with the saffron aioli and lemon wedges on the side. Enjoy!

While the rice cooks, in a small bowl, combine the mayonnaise and saffron powder; season with salt and pepper to taste. Set aside. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour and ½ cup of water; season with salt and pepper.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

stories.title: Saffron Powder
stories.description: At once delicate and powerful in flavor, saffron has long been one of the world’s most prized spices. Made from the crocus of the saffron flower, the powder is gorgeously red, and when added to a dish, it will often turn it a deep, striking yellow. Because it takes thousands of saffron crocuses to produce just one ounce of saffron powder, it is celebrated for its rarity. It has a complex, powerful aroma and taste—just the smallest pinch can add its distinct, unforgettable notes to a dish.

stories.title: Arborio Rice
stories.description: Because of its high concentration of a starch known as amylopectin, arborio rice has a unique texture when cooked: pleasantly creamy, but without losing its distinctive “bite”. This signature characteristic makes it a favorite rice for use in risotto. It’s named for the town of Arborio in the Piedmont region of Italy (where it was first grown). It has oval-shaped grains with a beautiful, pearly white exterior.

stories.title: Scallions
stories.description: Scallions, an onion relative, belong to a class of plants with undeveloped root bulbs and long, hollow leaves. They're milder than most other onion plants and delicious both cooked and raw. (In our recipes, you'll typically cook the white bottoms and use the green tops as garnish, reflecting the difference in their potency.) Scallions are a wonderful addition to everything from scrambled eggs to soups to stir-fries.

The most common lemons, which we use in virtually all of our dishes, are Eureka lemons. They've been grown in the United States (specifically California) since the 1850s, from Sicilian seeds. This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.title: English Peas
stories.description: Technically a kind of legume (like beans or lentils), peas are native to Western Asia. They’ve been cultivated since the Bronze Age. They spread to India and China by the 7th Century. (In Chinese, the word for pea translates to “foreign legume.”) During that time, peas (also called “field peas”) were quickly becoming a staple of European Medieval cuisine. These cuisines featured almost exclusively the pea itself (the seed of the plant). They’re still delicious and another sign that spring has sprung!

stories.title: All-Purpose Flour
stories.description: The term “all-purpose flour” is used to describe wheat flour with a low to moderate protein content. All-purpose flour has less protein than bread flour (which more easily forms gluten to make dense, chewy bread), but more protein than airy cake or pastry flour. It can be used in a wide variety of applications and is considered an essential pantry ingredient for bakers and chefs alike.

Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. stories.title: How To: Hold a Chef's Knife
stories.description: At the core of many knife skills in holding the knife properly. This simple grip gives you all the power and freedom you’ll need to prep whatever’s on your cutting board. So get a grip and watch this short video to see how it’s done!

recipe.title: Cheesy Broccoli Calzones with Tomato Dipping Sauce
recipe.description: In this recipe, we’re preparing traditional calzones with a filling of broccoli and two cheeses: fresh mozzarella and Parmesan. Briefly cooking the broccoli first ensures that its texture will be perfect once you bite into the crispy, golden-brown calzones. (Be sure to dry the florets well with paper towels before mixing them into the cheesy filling!) A side of simple, garlicky tomato sauce for dipping brightens up this hearty dinner.

stories.title: Pizza Dough
stories.description: Since its inception in 18th-Century Naples, pizza has become a global phenomenon. The base of any good pizza is a good pizza dough: typically a lean, yeast-leavened dough that bakes up to soft-on-the-inside, crispy-on-the-outside perfection in a hot pizza oven. Pizza dough has a much higher gluten content than regular bread dough, giving it enough elasticity to be stretched into a thin pie and creating a perfectly chewy bite when baked.

stories.title: Crushed Tomatoes
stories.description: Tomatoes first became popular in America during the Civil War, when the country found itself in need of foods that could be easily canned and shipped. The hardy tomato, which grew quickly and held up well in the canning process, rose to the occasion. Today, tomatoes are canned in many forms—whole, crushed, diced or as sauce or paste. Unlike canned tomato sauce, which is made by cooking tomatoes down until they become concentrated and smooth, crushed tomatoes come from fresh tomatoes that are ground, then often mixed with tomato purée before being canned. This results in a brighter, fresher flavor and chunkier texture than canned tomato sauce.

stories.title: Fresh Mozzarella
stories.description: Mozzarella is a mild cheese originally from Southern Italy. Like provolone and caciocavallo, the cheese is made using the "pasta filata" method. Milk is heated and the curds and whey are allowed to separate. The whey is then drained off, and the curds are steeped in hot water and kneaded until the cheese becomes ropy, elastic and supple. Long pieces are pulled out, cut and shaped into individual balls. The word mozzarella comes from the word mozzare, meaning "to cut," and refers to this last step in the cheese-making process. Mozzarella isn't aged, so it's best eaten fresh.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Broccoli
stories.description: From the Italian word “brocco,” meaning sprout or shoot, broccoli has long been enjoyed in Italy; the Romans especially adored it. Amazingly, this member of the cabbage family was unknown in the United States until the 1920s, when a pair of Italian immigrants began growing and selling the unfamiliar vegetable to American consumers. It quickly grew in popularity, and soon it was being cultivated and sold throughout the country.

stories.title: Parmesan Cheese
stories.description: Parmesan, or Parmigiano-Reggiano, is a hard cheese from Italy. It's named for the regions that produce it: Parma, Reggia Emilia, Bologna, Modena and Mantova. The name "Parmesan," and any translated form, is a protected designation of origin, meaning that only cheeses produced specifically in this region can be called "Parmesan." We can see why they would want to protect their name. This aged cheese has a distinct, granular texture and a unique, slightly nutty brininess that have made it one of the most popular European cheeses in the world. It's great for adding texture and flavor to pastas, but just as good shaved on top of salads (or eaten alone as a snack).

stories.title: Semolina Flour
stories.description: Semolina flour is a coarse, purified product made from durum wheat. (Durum flour is actually finely ground semolina.) It's most commonly used to make pastas, couscous and breakfast cereals. But in some parts of the world—particularly Eastern Europe, South Asia and North and West Africa—semolina flour is also boiled into soups and porridges (similar to the way ground corn is boiled to make grits). It can also be whipped into puddings and other sweet desserts.

stories.title: Italian Seasoning
stories.description: This classic spice blend combines many of the aromatic and zesty flavors beloved in Italian cuisine. Basil, oregano, rosemary, thyme and occasionally marjoram, savory or sage mingle harmoniously to bring big flavor to tomato sauce, pizzas, pastas and countless other dishes.

recipe_steps.step_text: Add the broccoli to the pot of boiling water. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 4 minutes, or until bright green and slightly softened. Drain thoroughly and rinse under cold water for 20 to 30 seconds to stop the cooking process. Thoroughly pat the drained broccoli dry with paper towels. Transfer to a cutting board and roughly chop. Transfer to a large bowl. Wipe out the pot.

Sprinkle the remaining flour onto a sheet pan. Carefully transfer the calzones to the prepared sheet pan; drizzle or brush the tops with olive oil. Bake 16 to 18 minutes, or until golden brown. Remove from the oven and let stand for at least 2 minutes. Transfer the baked calzones to a serving dish. Serve with the remaining tomato sauce on the side. Enjoy!
recipe_steps.step_title: Bake the calzones & serve your dish:

recipe_steps.step_text: In the pot used to cook the broccoli, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the garlic and season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring frequently, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until lightly browned and fragrant. Add the crushed tomatoes and Italian seasoning. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 4 minutes, or until thoroughly combined and heated through. Remove from heat and season with salt and pepper to taste.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe_steps.step_text: Preheat the oven to 475°F. Wash and dry the fresh produce. Remove the dough from the refrigerator to bring to room temperature. Heat a large pot of salted water to boiling on high. Cut the broccoli into bite-sized florets. Peel and mince the garlic. Tear the mozzarella cheese into bite-sized pieces.

stories.title: How To: Mince Garlic
stories.description: What would cooking be without garlic? Minced garlic helps create an amazing flavor base for virtually any meal. In this short video, chef Matt Wadiak will show you how to mince garlic in no time.

recipe_steps.step_text: Sprinkle half the flour onto a clean, dry work surface. Divide the dough into 4 equal-sized portions. Using your hands, gently stretch the portions into ¼-inch-thick rounds. (If the dough is resistant, let rest for 5 minutes.) Divide the filling between the centers of the rounds; fold each round in half over the filling. Using your fingers or a fork, press or crimp the edges of the dough to seal the calzones.
Add the Parmesan cheese, mozzarella cheese and â…“ of the tomato sauce to the bowl of chopped broccoli. Stir to thoroughly combine; season with salt and pepper to taste.

stories.title: How To: Properly Salt Cooking Water
stories.description: Seasoning cooking water (whether you're cooking pasta, vegetables or anything else) is imperative to building flavor. Check out this video to see how we do it!
